Accidental Release Prevention Policy:

Protecting and responsibly managing natural resources demonstrates stewardship and is critical to the quality of life in the communities we serve, to the environment, and to WTG Gas Processing, L.P. (WTG's) long-term business success.  Promoting the health and safety of co-workers, contractors, customers, and communities is the responsibility of all WTG employees.  WTG will meet all applicable laws, rules, and regulations.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:

Martin County Gas Plant ("Martin County") located near Stanton, Martin County, Texas is a natural gas treating and processing plant.  Sweet inlet gas enters the plant from high-pressure field gathering stations.  Martin County treats and processes flammable gas and liquid mixtures in an amount greater than the threshold quantity containing any of the following RMP-regulated constituents:

?    Methane

?    Ethane

?    Propane

?    Isobutane

?    Butane

?    Isopentane

?    Pentane

The only RMP-regulated toxic constituent present at Martin County, which is part of the liquid amine treating process, is hydrogen sulfide; however, quantities at this facility are well below the threshold quantity. 



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

WTG is committed to ensuring a safe work environment for all its employees, contractors, and vendors.  The Martin County Gas Plant has a detailed Emergency Response Plan which all employees are trained on and have readily available in their control room.  WTG conducts drills and coordinates annual mock emergency simulations at the Facility in conjunction with the local responders.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program:

The Martin County process is covered by OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of highly hazardous chemicals (PSM) regulation.  WTG considers the systems developed for compliance with PSM to be the basis for good safety and business practices.  In this effort, WTG identifies op

portunities to continuously improve initiatives for each PSM element.  The PSM elements are implemented to satisfy the PSM/RMP requirements since the Martin County Gas Plant qualifies as a program level 3 RMP process.



Employee Participation:

Employee participation is the foundation block to an evergreen and integrated PSM program.  Thus, the current PSM improvement initiative is heavily focused on this key element as employees are becoming more actively involved in the implementation of each element of PSM.



Process Safety Information:

Comprehensive reviews of the available process safety information (PSI) have been conducted.  Updates to the maximum intended inventory (MII) and piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs) have been completed.  Heat and material balances have been thoroughly documented.  A company-wide study is underway to ensure relief valves have been properly designed and sized for the specific application.  A comprehensive electronic web-based system utilized for timely access to information has been built, implemented, and made available to all personnel involved with operating the process.  



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):

A new PHA team including experienced operating personnel (operations and maintenance), WTG engineers, Process Control personnel, safety representatives, and PSM representatives conducted a PHA revalidation from July 6, 2020 through August 6, 2020.  The final report was published December 11, 2020 and contains an accompanying list of action items.  A tentative completion date for all action items is June 30, 2022; however, this is subject to change.  Results and recommendations from these analyses have been actively shared with employees.  Additionally, a process safety tracking tool has been developed and implemented for the interactive tracking of PHA action items to closure.  This tracking tool is used to generate reminders on a set frequency along with status updates of pending action items every month.



Operat

ing Procedures:

Written operating procedures with references to pertinent PSI are in the process of being developed.  A written mentorship training program has been developed, implemented, and documented per employee.  A technical review of operating procedures is currently underway and is being formatted into a standard operating procedures format adopted by WTG.  WTG will also be publishing operating procedures to the company's electronic web-based system.



Management of Change (MOC) and Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR):

Improvements to the MOC procedure and associated checklists are in progress to capture all process related changes.  Requirements for the identification, evaluation, control, and authorization of modifications to plant design and operations prior to the implementation to ensure that the risk of new or existing hazards are properly managed is available to all personnel.  Extensive PSSR checklists for applicable disciplines (electrical, instrumentation, procedures, etc.) have been developed and implemented.  These checklists are Appendices to the Company's MOC procedure and are available online from the company's electronic web-based process library. 



Mechanical Integrity (MI):

WTG is committed to maintaining the physical integrity of all equipment to prevent failures.  The MI program is being reestablished within WTG to include a MI computerized program that will integrate with the Company's maintenance program to track the code required inspection requirements of all affected equipment and document equipment history accordingly.  This process is being developed in conjunction with the revised comprehensive inspection standards and procedures for all WTG sites.  



Incident Investigation:

WTG investigates all PSM incidents.  Throughout the PSM program assessment process, incident investigation procedures are being reviewed and will be updated as necessary.  A mix of WTG personnel will be provided investigation methodology training to furt

her enhance the program and ensure root cause is consistently identified.  A process safety tracking tool has been developed and implemented to track action items and incident investigation corrective actions to closure.



Compliance Audits:

To meet compliance with PSM/RMP, WTG conducts compliance audits every three years to verify all PSM/RMP element requirements are being satisfied.  In WTG's general PSM/RMP improvement program initiatives, an updated audit protocol has been established and implemented within WTG.  



Hot Work Permit:

Hot work permits are in use and on file.  These permits are uploaded onto the company's electronic web-based process library.  Throughout the PSM program assessment process, all hot work procedures are being reviewed and will be updated as necessary.



Contractors:

WTG uses a web-based system for contractors that maintains required insurance, training and safety records.  A review of the contractor's safety record both prior to selection and during their time of employment is being developed.



Training:

With the enhancement of various PSM elements such as PSI, PHAs, operating procedures, PSSR, MI, MOC, incident investigations, etc., additional training (computer and classroom based) have been and will continue to be established to ensure all Martin County employees are knowledgeable in these processes.



Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:

The process at Martin County has hazards that must be managed for continued safe operation.  Following is a description of existing safety features applicable to prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility.



Universal Prevention Activities

The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to the RMP-covered process at Martin County.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.



Specialized Safety Features:



The Martin County Gas

Plant has safety features on many units to help:

I.    contain/control a release

II.    quickly detect a release; and

III.    reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release.

Release Detection

I.    Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms located throughout the process along with automatic shutoff of natural gas compressors

II.    Fire eyes located within each compressor building and connected to the automatic shutoff of the natural gas compressors 

III.    Remote emergency shutdown for all inlet gas pipeline valves

IV.    Hydrogen sulfide detectors with alarms located in designated process areas

V.    Routine operator rounds/equipment inspections

VI.    Operators are on-site continually (8,760 hours per year)



Release containment/control measures include:

I.    Main process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases

II.    Automated and manual valves to permit isolation of the process

III.    Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high temperature)

IV.    Curbing to contain liquid releases

V.    Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system)

VI.    Atmospheric relief devices.



Release mitigation measures include:

I.    Fire extinguishing systems

II.    Personnel trained in emergency action

III.    Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)



Emergency Response Program:

Since the last RMP renewal, WTG has developed and implemented a company-wide standard for Emergency Response Plans, as well as site-specific emergency response plan checklists.  All Martin County staff have completed training on both items.  The emergency response checklist outlines site location information; contact information for key WTG and Martin County staff, emergency responders, and neighboring medical facilities; the location of each emergency shutdown device, each of which can initiate a complete plant shutdown; and includes evacuation routes

and checklists that outline all needed action items depending on the type of emergency, such as serious injury/medical emergency, major loss of process containment, minor loss of process containment, fire/explosion, severe weather, and security threat.  The overall emergency response program for Martin County is coordinated with the Martin County Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC).  Several local emergency responders that support Martin County include Martin County Emergency Services, the Martin County Sheriff, and the Martin County (Stanton) Fire Department.  The Martin County Gas Plant has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department, Police and Sheriff's offices).  This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  Martin County is planning its first annual (2021) mock emergency drill that will involve local emergency response organizations.



Five-Year Accident History:

All incidents that occurred within the previous five years were reviewed to determine whether any are subject to RMP reporting.  There have been no accidental releases of regulated substances meeting the accident reporting criteria of 40 CFR 68.42(a) during the prior five years at the Martin County Gas Plant.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

WTG Martin County will continue to improve its safety and environmental performance through emphasis on the continued development of its PSM Program.  Improvement plans include process engineering support to update critical PSI data for the site; operating procedures written for each mode of operation and to include consequences of deviations; an operator certification training program established from the new operating procedures, new process hazard analysis (PHA) procedure and team structure ensuring employee involvement, new MI program incorporating the implementation of all new ins
pection procedures and frequencies all to be carefully reviewed, and recommendations for improvement generated using WTG's new compliance audit process.
